title: ID Masthead Fonts
content:
Hello,

Could anyone ID the following masthead fonts:

1.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140126045955im_/http:/typophile.com/files/COM_4925.jpg)

2.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140126045955im_/http:/typophile.com/files/TSKBD_3579.jpg)

3.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140126045955im_/http:/typophile.com/files/VIBE_3576.jpg)

Thanks so much for your time.
author: tm6464

comments.content:
Vibe is Vibration from Font Bureau  
 [http://typophile.com/node/33071](http://web.archive.org/web/20140126045955/http:/typophile.com/node/33071 "http://typophile.com/node/33071")
Ouch! Who cares about the font on the first sample?

"Vibe is Vibration"

Vibration designed for Vibe or Vibe designer making a clever inside type joke? ;o)

While Vibe probably was using Vibration Gothic from Font Bureau at the time that cover was printed, I think the logo/flag\* is/was a custom design based on Helvetica or a more recent sans. Vibration Gothic, like Titling Gothic, has the feel of an older, Akzidenz Grotesk-like sans.

\*We magazine designers prefer that to "masthead," which is the listing of the staff/contributors.

To all the magazine designers, I apologize. I mispoke when I referred to the font type as mastheads

I was actually thinking about one issue, while writing on another. Please excuse the error.

Hey, no offense taken. I should have added a :) so you'd know that it wasn't a big deal.

It's a losing battle, anyway. Even some of my colleagues (fellow designers and editors) call the thing at the top of the front cover "the masthead." Sure, I secretly look down on them, but...

COMPLEX looks like something from [Fontalicious](http://web.archive.org/web/20140126045955/http:/www.fontbros.com/cgi-bin/commerce.cgi?search=action&category=1060&keywords=all), perhaps a custom blend done for the magazine. What first made me look at these was the font Rolloglide (shown [here](http://web.archive.org/web/20140126045955/http:/www.bowfinprintworks.com/LinedFontGuide03.html) in the Lined Fonts Guide)-- imagine a solid version of Rolloglide with the C (alt) from Gemini on the FontBros page.

- Mike Yanega
Also: 493 ways to ball!? SO MANY!

...  
Some balls are held for charity  
And some for fancy dress  
But when they’re held for pleasure  
They’re the balls that I like best.  
...  
_-Bon Scott-_
